answers.a: Industrial tagatose is typically made by hydrolyzing lactose (from whey) to galactose and then enzymatically isomerizing the galactose to D‑tagatose; newer processes can start from plant sugars using microbial enzymes.
Tagatose (E963) is a low‑calorie rare sugar used as a bulk sweetener, about 90% as sweet as sucrose and providing roughly 1.5 kcal/g with a low glycemic impact.

answers.q: below is the open-chain of the monosaccharide d-tagatose, which is the ketohexose
answers.a: D‑Tagatose is a ketohexose (the C‑4 epimer of D‑fructose) whose open‑chain form has a ketone at C‑2 and cyclizes in solution to furanose or pyranose rings.

answers.q: below is the open-chain structure of the monosaccharide d-tagatose, which is a ketohexose. like most monosaccharides, it has more than one chiral carbon. select all of the chiral carbon atoms.
answers.a: In the open‑chain D‑tagatose, the chiral centers are C‑3, C‑4, and C‑5.

answers.q: haworth projection tagatose which carbon supplies the oh
answers.a: For ring formation, the OH on C‑5 typically attacks C‑2 to give the furanose, while the OH on C‑6 can attack C‑2 to give the pyranose.
